pull.title: depends: always use correct ar for win qt build
pull.body:
If we don't set this explicitly, then qt will still use it's default
windows ar, when building with LTO (when we want it to use gcc-ar).

So set `QMAKE_LIB` which is used for win32, and defaults to `ar rc`, to `our_ar rc`.
This way we always get the correct ar.

Issue can be seen building in Guix with LTO. i.e:
```bash
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/hb-blob.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
```

verification.payload:
tree 7b7d93f3869bbed47eed597ffe1a101bab75480e
parent aa22009887eba6b6afdc530cfbcbe98e8aa34434
author fanquake <fanquake@gmail.com> 1658824722 +0100
committer fanquake <fanquake@gmail.com> 1658824722 +0100

depends: always use correct ar for win qt

If we don't set this explicitly, then qt will still use it's default
windows ar, when building with LTO (when we want it to use gcc-ar).

So set `QMAKE_LIB` which is used for win32, and defaults to `ar -rc`.
This way we always get the correct ar.

Issue can be seen building in Guix with LTO. i.e:
```bash
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/hb-blob.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
```

events.message:
depends: always use correct ar for win qt

If we don't set this explicitly, then qt will still use it's default
windows ar, when building with LTO (when we want it to use gcc-ar).

So set `QMAKE_LIB` which is used for win32, and defaults to `ar -rc`.
This way we always get the correct ar.

Issue can be seen building in Guix with LTO. i.e:
```bash
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/hb-blob.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
```

events.body:
Both on master and with this PR still not able to cross compile for Windows with `LTO=1`:
```
./configure CONFIG_SITE=$PWD/depends/x86_64-w64-mingw32/share/config.site
...
checking for QWindowsIntegrationPlugin (-lqwindows)... yes
checking for QWindowsVistaStylePlugin (-lqwindowsvistastyle)... no
configure: WARNING: QWindowsVistaStylePlugin not found.; bitcoin-qt frontend will not be built
checking whether to build Bitcoin Core GUI... no
...
```
and an excerpt from the `config.log`:
```
...
/usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld: simplewidgets.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn40_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): multiple definition of `QAccessibleLineEdit::~QAccessibleLineEdit()'; rangecontrols.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn16_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): first defined here
/usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld: simplewidgets.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn40_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): multiple definition of `non-virtual thunk to QAccessibleLineEdit::~QAccessibleLineEdit()'; rangecontrols.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn16_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): first defined here
/usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld: simplewidgets.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn40_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): multiple definition of `non-virtual thunk to QAccessibleLineEdit::~QAccessibleLineEdit()'; rangecontrols.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn16_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): first defined here
/usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld: simplewidgets.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn40_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): multiple definition of `non-virtual thunk to QAccessibleLineEdit::~QAccessibleLineEdit()'; rangecontrols.o (symbol from plugin):(.gnu.linkonce.t._ZN19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev[_ZThn16_N19QAccessibleLineEditD1Ev]+0x0): first defined here
...
```

> Both on master and with this PR still not able to cross compile for Windows with LTO=1:

Yes. That is expected, and not being fixed here.

> Issue can be seen building in Guix with LTO. i.e:
> 
> ```shell
> x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/hb-blob.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
> ```

Confirming:
```
$ env HOSTS=x86_64-w64-mingw32 ./contrib/guix/guix-build &> ~/guix-win-lto.log
$ cat ~/guix-win-lto.log | grep -e 'plugin needed to handle lto object'
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/pcre2_auto_possess.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/qstring_compat.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/qtmain_win.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/png.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/hb-blob.o: plugin needed to handle lto object

x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/qedidparser.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/qabstractfileiconengine.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/qdevicediscovery_dummy.o: plugin needed to handle lto object
x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar: .obj/release/qaccessiblebridgeutils.o: plugin needed to handle lto object

ACK 30091807514470f51bee6057905415ddc853ca53, tested on Ubuntu 22.04.

Although the `QMAKE_LIB` is not [documented](https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qmake-variable-reference.html), its meaning becomes clear from the [`mkspecs/common/g++-win32.conf`](https://github.com/qt/qtbase/blob/v5.15.3-lts-lgpl/mkspecs/common/g%2B%2B-win32.conf#L71) file:
```
QMAKE_LIB               = $${CROSS_COMPILE}ar -rc
```
